The picture that's selected is sent to a server tho. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Thomas Brewster \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/iblametom\">@iblametom<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/iblametom\/status\/1151488144157663238\">I'll clarify a little on this: If you're concerned about your face and some mobile data possibly being replicated back to Russia via Amazon, don't use the app. I personally wouldn't use it. I wouldn't use a lot of apps, Russian or otherwise, given the privacy infringements. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Matthew Panzarino \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\">@panzer<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\/status\/1151311303471853569\">Because the user has to tap on one photo, this provides something Apple holds dear: user intent. You have explicitly tapped it, so it's ok. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Rosie Gray \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/rosiegray\">@rosiegray<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/rosiegray\/status\/1151550332285136896\">i wouldn't put my face in the FaceApp old thing for less than $500<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Bob Cesca \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bobcesca_go\">@bobcesca_go<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bobcesca_go\/status\/1151519048582205440\">-\"You grant FaceApp a perpetual, irrevocable royalty-free license to use, adapt, publish, distribute your user content in all media formats when you post or share\" -\"hackers (and Russian gov by proxy) can cross-reference your face and phone info w the websites you're using 2\/3<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>David Carroll \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/profcarroll\">@profcarroll<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/profcarroll\/status\/1151560993908150273\">Contradictory statements from FaceApp CEO with what's stated in their privacy policy. So, like all apps (yes, American apps too, sheesh), use at your own risk, think twice. EU residents should know that FaceApp is likely not GDPR compliant, in any event. https:\/\/www.washingtonpost.com\/ ...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Dan Kaminsky \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/dakami\">@dakami<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/dakami\/status\/1151554396573949952\">Faceapp, to old people: OMG YOUR FACE TO RUSSIA Faceapp, to slightly less old people: OMG YOUR FACE TO ANYBODY Faceapp, to kids: OMG SHUT YOUR FACE this is funny stop being so scared of everything it's stupid<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Matthew Panzarino \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\">@panzer<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\/status\/1151311297822150656\">FaceApp. So. The app has gone viral again after first doing so two years ago or so. The effect has gotten better but these apps, like many other one off viral apps, tend to come and go in waves driven by influencer networks or paid promotion. https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE><A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/blobyblo\">@blobyblo<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/blobyblo\/status\/1151447470959779841\">does everyone doing the faceapp aging thing first think oh this is neat as they giggle and share and then immediately fall into silent contemplation about mortality or is it just me<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Matthew Panzarino \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\">@panzer<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\/status\/1151311312967761920\">Given how many screenshots people take of sensitive information like banking and whatnot, photo access is a bigger security risk than ever these days. With a scraper and OCR you could automatically turn up a huge amount of info way beyond &lsquo;photos of people&rsquo;.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Seth Fiegerman \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sfiegerman\">@sfiegerman<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sfiegerman\/status\/1151499378152169472\">FaceApp's virality is a damning reminder that we as consumers have learned nothing from the last two years of privacy scandals. If an app looks fun, we don't ask questions. Remember: Cambridge Analytica started with a personality quiz. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Matthew Panzarino \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\">@panzer<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\/status\/1151311299948605440\">In this current wave of virality, some new rumors are floating about FaceApp. The first is that it uploads your camera roll in the background. We found no evidence of this and neither did @chronic https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Nicole Perlroth \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nicoleperlroth\">@nicoleperlroth<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nicoleperlroth\/status\/1151531031444410368\">Good job submitting millions of faces to a St. Petersburg, Russia based app with a horrific privacy policy that will likely pass this on to state, facial recognition databases, everyone in my Twitter feed. You   have   learned   nothing.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Lachlan Markay \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lachlan\">@lachlan<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lachlan\/status\/1151551989056249857\">Nice try FaceApp, but I'm not gonna give some anonymous AI developer permanent access to my likeness for anything less than *carries the 1, multiplies by follower count* 63 retweets.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Matthew Panzarino \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\">@panzer<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\/status\/1151311310220484608\">One thing that FaceApp does do, however, is it uploads your photo to the cloud for processing. It does not do on-device processing like Apple's first party app does and like it enables for third parties through its ML libraries and routines. This is not made clear to the user.<\/A><\/DIV><\/DIV>\n<DIV CLASS=\"exm\" ID=\"1dxr\" STYLE=\"display:block;\"><A HREF=\"javascript:tgd('1',true)\">Expand More For Next<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"exm\" ID=\"5i1\">\n<table class=\"shrtbl\"><tr><td>\n<CITE>Brian Merchant \/ <A HREF=\"http:\/\/www.cjr.org\/\">Columbia Journalism Review<\/A>:<\/CITE>\n<\/td><td><span id=\"s5i1\" pml=\"190717p28\" twid=\"1151571292736372736\"><\/span><\/td><\/tr><\/table>\n<DIV CLASS=\"ii\"><A HREF=\"https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/opinion\/tech-journalism-on-background.php\"><IMG CLASS=\"ill\" SRC=\"\/190717\/i28.jpg\"><\/A>\n<STRONG CLASS=\"L2\"><A CLASS=\"ourh\" HREF=\"https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/opinion\/tech-journalism-on-background.php\">To duck accountability, &ldquo;on background&rdquo; has become the default method by which Silicon Valley disseminates information, often abetted by tech journalists<\/A><\/STRONG>&nbsp; &mdash;&nbsp; One of the most pernicious tools that Silicon Valley uses to control the flow of information to the public is decidedly low-tech: briefing reporters &ldquo;on background.&rdquo;<\/DIV>\n<DIV ID=\"5d1\"><DIV CLASS=\"dbpt\">\n<DIV ID=\"5dx1\" style=\"display:none\" class=\"dxd\"><table><tr><td class=\"dxcol\" ONCLICK=\"tgd('5',true,1);\"><\/td><\/tr><\/table><\/DIV>\n<SPAN CLASS=\"drhed\">Tweets:<\/SPAN>&nbsp;<span class=\"bls\"><A other side and have a reporter call you up and try to get you on record commenting on really outrageous issues or allegations. https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Brian exploiting &lsquo;on background&rsquo; with us journalists for too long&mdash;it's become a scourge, and it's time to unite to destroy it. Me in @CJR: https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Alex Kantrowitz \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/kantrowitz\">@kantrowitz<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/kantrowitz\/status\/1151516669333762049\">I'm with @bcmerchant on this one. Tech companies spinning on background is a scrouge and needs to stop. &ldquo;A spokesperson should either go on the record or get off the phone.&rdquo; https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/... https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Brian Merchant \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bcmerchant\">@bcmerchant<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bcmerchant\/status\/1151611986360205312\">Hey everyone guess what an Instagram rep sent me in an email after I asked for comment for a story *today*: A reply under a bolded header reading &lsquo;On Background&rsquo;, which I in no way consented to. Just perfect https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Charles Arthur \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/charlesarthur\">@charlesarthur<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/charlesarthur\/status\/1151577760403533833\">Brian is so right about this: the big tech companies use &ldquo;on background&rdquo; as a way to evade having their name attached to stuff. It's a means of evading responsibility, and journalism shouldn't enable that. (Very much easier said than done when you need a quote.) https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Sal \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sal19\">@sal19<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sal19\/status\/1151539859527389185\">&ldquo;Good, aggressive reporters are regularly pushing back against these ossified norms. We all should join them, and now. Tech PR shops exist solely to paint their employers in a flattering light; they can do so on the record.&rdquo; https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Zo Bernard \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/zoesaintbernard\">@zoesaintbernard<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/zoesaintbernard\/status\/1151547982829035520\">it's rare that i get anyone in a position of power in silicon valley to go on the record w\/ even the most mild-mannered opinion, much less company PR https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Gideon Lichfield \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/glichfield\">@glichfield<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/glichfield\/status\/1151528925979394048\">&ldquo;I decided that on all matters of importance, I am no longer going to listen to a public relations representative try to change my mind on background with unquotable statements attributable to no one.&rdquo; We should all adopt @bcmerchant's policy (HT @jtemple) https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Michael Calore \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/snackfight\">@snackfight<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/snackfight\/status\/1151561738942238720\">&ldquo;If an actual source&mdash;an engineer, or a policymaker&mdash;wants to go on background for protection, that's one thing. But a spokesperson should either go on the record or get off the phone.&rdquo; https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/... via @cjr<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>James Temple \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jtemple\">@jtemple<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jtemple\/status\/1151526940488024065\">Glad to see this @CJR piece calling out big tech's background only media strategies, which they employ to force outlets to articulate their positions (and criticisms) for them https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Martin Sfp Bryant \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/martinsfp\">@martinsfp<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/martinsfp\/status\/1151537256630562822\">Journalists often accept &lsquo;on background&rsquo; because it's better than no comment at all. But it allows tech companies to get their point across without taking any flak if their position backfires. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Tony Romm \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/tonyromm\">@tonyromm<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/tonyromm\/status\/1151572979748364288\">susan raises good points here &mdash; you have to understand why people are asking for background in order to know the best way to approach it, then negotiate or navigate accordingly. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Brian Merchant \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bcmerchant\">@bcmerchant<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bcmerchant\/status\/1151516002754056192\">This piece was inspired by\/rage-written after a long string of run-ins with the biggest tech companies going&mdash;every single convo I've had with them has been &lsquo;on background&rsquo; this year&mdash;and by how @reckless, @thetomzone &amp; @kellybourdet handled the YouTube Maza\/Crowder snafu.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Dr Karlin Lillington \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/klillington\">@klillington<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/klillington\/status\/1151543858968375296\">A routine ask of tech journalists. Recalling one event at Facebook Dublin, a &lsquo;briefing&rsquo; on security\/privacy, &amp; only on arrival did they say it was a &lsquo;background briefing&rsquo;. PS haven't been invited back since &mdash; Tech journalism's &lsquo;on background&rsquo; scourge https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Ali Breland \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/alibreland\">@alibreland<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/alibreland\/status\/1151545093297324032\">this is good and true. massively powerful tech companies spend so much time behind the scenes sending &ldquo;background info,&rdquo; which is often just info intended silently influence the perspective of the reporter without the reader ever knowing https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Rob Pegoraro \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/robpegoraro\">@robpegoraro<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; (turnOnExcerptDelayTimer)\nclearTimeout(turnOnExcerptDelayTimer);\nshowDiscussionExcerpt(excerptId);\n} else\nshowExcerptTimer = setTimeout(function() {\nshowDiscussionExcerpt(excerptId);\nif This looks like the lowest quarter for subscriber growth since at least 2016, trying to nail that down. $NFLX falling fast, down 9% right now. https:\/\/on.mktw.net\/2XXRDXI<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Lucas Shaw \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lucas_shaw\">@lucas_shaw<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lucas_shaw\/status\/1151592043069825024\">Netflix's overall spending on programming appears to have plateaued at about $19 billion.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Andrew Wallenstein \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/awallenstein\">@awallenstein<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/awallenstein\/status\/1151587035120975872\">More Netflix spin on all the new competition coming its way. Translation: &ldquo;Well, they're not really competitors so much as they are other market entrants that will help demonstrate to consumers the power of streaming.&rdquo; A rising tide isn't guaranteed to lift your boat, Reed... pic.twitter.com\/YnhnGar9in<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Peter Kafka \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/pkafka\">@pkafka<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/pkafka\/status\/1151584950703067147\">Netflix says Always Be My Maybe, which everybody in my TL was chatting about, was watched by 32 million people in its first month. Adam Sandler's Murder Mystery, discussed by zero people I know, was watched by 73 million people.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Andrew Wallenstein \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/awallenstein\">@awallenstein<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/awallenstein\/status\/1151586009580052481\">Gotta love Netflix spin on losing Friends and The Office: now we have more $$ to spend on original content! If an app looks fun, we don't ask questions. Remember: Cambridge Analytica started with a personality quiz. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Matthew Panzarino \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\">@panzer<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\/status\/1151311299948605440\">In this current wave of virality, some new rumors are floating about FaceApp. The first is that it uploads your camera roll in the background. We found no evidence of this and neither did @chronic https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Nicole Perlroth \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nicoleperlroth\">@nicoleperlroth<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nicoleperlroth\/status\/1151531031444410368\">Good job submitting millions of faces to a St. Petersburg, Russia based app with a horrific privacy policy that will likely pass this on to state, facial recognition databases, everyone in my Twitter feed. You   have   learned   nothing.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Lachlan Markay \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lachlan\">@lachlan<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lachlan\/status\/1151551989056249857\">Nice try FaceApp, but I'm not gonna give some anonymous AI developer permanent access to my likeness for anything less than *carries the 1, multiplies by follower count* 63 retweets.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Matthew Panzarino \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\">@panzer<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/panzer\/status\/1151311310220484608\">One thing that FaceApp does do, however, is it uploads your photo to the cloud for processing. It does not do on-device processing like Apple's first party app does and like it enables for third parties through its ML libraries and routines. This is not made clear to the user.<\/A><\/DIV><\/DIV>\n<DIV CLASS=\"exm\" ID=\"1dxr\" STYLE=\"display:block;\"><A HREF=\"javascript:tgd('1',true)\">Expand More For Next<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"exm\" ID=\"5i1\">\n<table class=\"shrtbl\"><tr><td>\n<CITE>Brian Merchant \/ <A HREF=\"http:\/\/www.cjr.org\/\">Columbia Journalism Review<\/A>:<\/CITE>\n<\/td><td><span id=\"s5i1\" pml=\"190717p28\" twid=\"1151571292736372736\"><\/span><\/td><\/tr><\/table>\n<DIV CLASS=\"ii\"><A HREF=\"https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/opinion\/tech-journalism-on-background.php\"><IMG CLASS=\"ill\" SRC=\"\/190717\/i28.jpg\"><\/A>\n<STRONG CLASS=\"L2\"><A CLASS=\"ourh\" HREF=\"https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/opinion\/tech-journalism-on-background.php\">To duck accountability, &ldquo;on background&rdquo; has become the default method by which Silicon Valley disseminates information, often abetted by tech journalists<\/A><\/STRONG>&nbsp; &mdash;&nbsp; One of the most pernicious tools that Silicon Valley uses to control the flow of information to the public is decidedly low-tech: briefing reporters &ldquo;on background.&rdquo;<\/DIV>\n<DIV ID=\"5d1\"><DIV CLASS=\"dbpt\">\n<DIV ID=\"5dx1\" style=\"display:none\" class=\"dxd\"><table><tr><td class=\"dxcol\" ONCLICK=\"tgd('5',true,1);\"><\/td><\/tr><\/table><\/DIV>\n<SPAN CLASS=\"drhed\">Tweets:<\/SPAN>&nbsp;<span class=\"bls\"><A Me in @CJR: https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Alex Kantrowitz \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/kantrowitz\">@kantrowitz<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/kantrowitz\/status\/1151516669333762049\">I'm with @bcmerchant on this one. Just perfect https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Charles Arthur \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/charlesarthur\">@charlesarthur<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/charlesarthur\/status\/1151577760403533833\">Brian is so right about this: the big tech companies use &ldquo;on background&rdquo; as a way to evade having their name attached to stuff. It's a means of evading responsibility, and journalism shouldn't enable that. (Very much easier said than done when you need a quote.) https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Sal \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sal19\">@sal19<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sal19\/status\/1151539859527389185\">&ldquo;Good, aggressive reporters are regularly pushing back against these ossified norms. We all should join them, and now. Tech PR shops exist solely to paint their employers in a flattering light; they can do so on the record.&rdquo; https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Zo Bernard \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/zoesaintbernard\">@zoesaintbernard<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/zoesaintbernard\/status\/1151547982829035520\">it's rare that i get anyone in a position of power in silicon valley to go on the record w\/ even the most mild-mannered opinion, much less company PR https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Gideon Lichfield \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/glichfield\">@glichfield<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/glichfield\/status\/1151528925979394048\">&ldquo;I decided that on all matters of importance, I am no longer going to listen to a public relations representative try to change my mind on background with unquotable statements attributable to no one.&rdquo; We should all adopt @bcmerchant's policy (HT @jtemple) https:\/\/www.cjr.org\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Michael Calore \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/snackfight\">@snackfight<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/snackfight\/status\/1151561738942238720\">&ldquo;If an actual source&mdash;an engineer, or a policymaker&mdash;wants to go on background for protection, that's one thing. But it allows tech companies to get their point across without taking any flak if their position backfires. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Tony Romm \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/tonyromm\">@tonyromm<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/tonyromm\/status\/1151572979748364288\">susan raises good points here &mdash; you have to understand why people are asking for background in order to know the best way to approach it, then negotiate or navigate accordingly. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Brian Merchant \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bcmerchant\">@bcmerchant<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bcmerchant\/status\/1151516002754056192\">This piece was inspired by\/rage-written after a long string of run-ins with the biggest tech companies going&mdash;every single convo I've had with them has been &lsquo;on background&rsquo; this year&mdash;and by how @reckless, @thetomzone &amp; @kellybourdet handled the YouTube Maza\/Crowder snafu.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Dr Karlin Lillington \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/klillington\">@klillington<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/klillington\/status\/1151543858968375296\">A routine ask of tech journalists. <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/mcquillanator\/status\/1151621568331755520\">Bye, bye Instagram likes: users in NZ, Australia, Brazil, Japan, Italy and Ireland will no longer have a public &ldquo;like&rdquo; count on their photos. Tests of the private &ldquo;like&rdquo; count started here in Canada in May and tbh I'm coping fine, thanks for asking https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE><A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/instagram\">@instagram<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/instagram\/status\/1151605660812890114\">We're looking forward to learning more about how this change might benefit everyone's experience on Instagram.<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Taylor Soper \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/taylor_soper\">@taylor_soper<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/taylor_soper\/status\/1151605487948845057\">Goodbye likes? https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE><A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/instagram\">@instagram<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/instagram\/status\/1151605660150194176\">We want your friends to focus on the photos and videos you share, not how many likes they get. You can still see your own likes by tapping on the list of people who've liked it, but your friends will not be able to see how many likes your post has received.<\/A><\/DIV><\/DIV>\n<\/DIV>\n<\/DIV><\/DIV><\/DIV>\n<\/DIV>\n<DIV CLASS=\"clus\">\n<A NAME=\"a190717p32\"><\/A>\n<DIV CLASS=\"itc1\" ONMOUSEOVER=\"overitem(16,true,1)\" ONMOUSEOUT=\"overitem(16,false,1)\"><DIV CLASS=\"itc2\" ID=\"190717p32\"><DIV CLASS=\"last item\" ID=\"16i1\">\n<table class=\"shrtbl\"><tr><td>\n<CITE>Natalie Gagliordi \/ <A HREF=\"http:\/\/www.zdnet.com\/\">ZDNet<\/A>:<\/CITE>\n<\/td><td><span id=\"s16i1\" pml=\"190717p32\" twid=\"1151597842248679424\"><\/span><\/td><\/tr><\/table>\n<DIV CLASS=\"ii\"><A HREF=\"https:\/\/www.zdnet.com\/article\/ebay-beats-q2-estimates-confirms-potential-stubhub-sale\/\"><IMG CLASS=\"ill\" SRC=\"\/190717\/i32.jpg\"><\/A>\n<STRONG CLASS=\"L1\"><A CLASS=\"ourh\" HREF=\"https:\/\/www.zdnet.com\/article\/ebay-beats-q2-estimates-confirms-potential-stubhub-sale\/\">eBay beats with Q2 revenue of $2.7B, up 2% YoY, net income of $403M, and says it is considering selling both StubHub and its Classifieds services; CB Insights reports that blockchain investments are on track to be down 60% this year. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Kontra \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/counternotions\">@counternotions<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/counternotions\/status\/1151499297181097986\">IBM: &ldquo;I certainly think there has been a share of hype associated with blockchain.&rdquo; Nasdaq: &ldquo;To be honest, the value differentiation using blockchain from using traditional technology has not been obvious.&rdquo; (ElOhEl, Avenue Of Broken Dreams! ) https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>John W. \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/_johnwhelan\">@_johnwhelan<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/_johnwhelan\/status\/1151246913880186881\">Accurate article. The big problem for &ldquo;enterprise #blockchain&rdquo;? Too much focus on use cases and not enough focus on spinning up a chain that will last beyond a pilot. Challenge to the banking industry: let's spin up a chain with 25+ validator and open it up for development. https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Eric van Miltenburg \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/ericvanm\">@ericvanm<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/ericvanm\/status\/1151274864096841728\">Evidence of what @Ripple has been saying for years - you can't haphazardly incorporate blockchain into a business strategy and expect it to work, you need an actual use case leveraging proven technology and partnerships with regulators to succeed. https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Matt Asay \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/mjasay\">@mjasay<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/mjasay\/status\/1151137253801857026\">Desperately seeking customer problems to solve. There must be some, but vendors seem more interested in selling blockchain than customers seem interested in buying it https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE><A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/reuters\">@reuters<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/reuters\/status\/1151145911805992961\">Tough to tame: Euphoria surrounding early days of Wall Street's interest in blockchain gives way to pragmatism, as companies realize that it will likely take years before it takes off https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/... https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Patrick \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/pmylund\">@pmylund<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/pmylund\/status\/1151151994175938561\">Huge corporations don't adopt *anything* in the span of a few years, much less exotic crypto (MPC, SNARKs, even relatively simple kinds of signatures.) flexible electrodes via small holes. Good progress on channel count + insertion, building on @m8ta's work. Also nice chip+packaging. Hard stuff. Much depends on gliosis, but Chong Xie's results promising. Laser would indeed be preferable to drill. 1\/4 https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Sean Carroll \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/seanmcarroll\">@seanmcarroll<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/seanmcarroll\/status\/1151379446156255233\">Brain-computer interfaces could have an enormous impact if they become widely affordable and effective. Imagine the apps of a smartphone, but connected directly to your brain. Neuralink is taking baby steps, but there's going to be a lot of competition. https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE><A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/business\">@business<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/business\/status\/1151353059739459584\">Elon Musk explains his startup's Neuralink brain tech features: -extremely tiny &ldquo;threads&rdquo; about the size of a neuron -robotic system for inserting electrodes into brain -powerful sensors https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/... https:\/\/twitter.com\/...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Antonio Regalado \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/antonioregalado\">@antonioregalado<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/antonioregalado\/status\/1151143771196788737\">A Neuralink founder is now questioning whether the Elon Musk brain-interface company is rushing too fast to get a high-bandwidth connection to human brains. https:\/\/www.technologyreview.com\/ ...<\/A><\/DIV><DIV CLASS=\"di\"><CITE>Bryan William Jones \/ <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bwjones\">@bwjones<\/A>:<\/CITE> &nbsp; <A HREF=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bwjones\/status\/1151336607963742209\">The thing that *NOBODY* is addressing, or has dealt with is the gliosis involved with implantation of electrodes in nervous tissue.
